Box 80203 Jeddah 21589 Saudi Arabia Graphical abstract In this study, Au-Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (Au-CeZr) and Sm modified AuCeZr catalysts were synthesized by organic deposition-precipitation method using gold acetate and samarium acetate as Au and Sm precursors and tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide as precipitating agent. The synthesized nanocrystalline Au-CeZr and Sm modified Au-CeZr materials found be effective catalysts for benzyl alcohol oxidation at low reaction temperatures. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM, DRIFT spectra after pyridine adsorption, N2-physisorption, XPS and H2-TPR techniques. The Au nanoparticles are highly dispersed on CeZr support and XRD reflections due to presence of Au metal were not observed for the samples which contained less than 1.0 wt% Au. The XPS and H2-TPR results revealed that at lower Au loadings, strong Au-CeZr interaction resulted an easy exclusion of surface oxygen ions in Au-CeZr and Sm-Au-CeZr catalysts. Pyridine adsorption results indicated an increase of Lewis acid sites of the CeZr support after Au deposition and Sm modification. The 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalyst is most active and selective catalysts for benzyl alcohol oxidation among the synthesized catalysts due to optimum loading of Au and Sm. An optimal surface acidity and redox properties is accountable for the improved catalytic activity of 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalyst in the benzyl alcohol oxidation. Keywords Gold Samarium Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 Organic deposition-precipitation Benzyl alcohol Oxidation 1 Introduction In recent years, selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde is of considerable importance in the industry, because benzaldehyde is considered a versatile chemical and widely used as a starting material in perfumery, cosmetic, pharmaceutical, dyestuff, flavoring and agro chemical industries [1,2]. Traditionally, benzyl alcohol oxidation was performed using various hazardous and expensive inorganic oxidants, such as hypochlorite, manganese (IV) oxide, permanganate, chromium (IV) oxide and dichromate [3–6]. With growing environmental concern, clean oxidants like molecular oxygen and aqueous hydrogen peroxide are preferred as water is the only main side product of these reactions [5]. Choudary and co-workers first tested benzyl alcohol oxidation in liquid phase by using a range of transition metals catalysts supported on hydrotalcite-like supports without the use of any solvent [6]. Among the numerous non-noble metals tested for the reaction, Cu and Mn catalysts were proved to be the most active but with low selectivity towards benzaldehyde and with the need of high reaction temperature 210 °C. Typical noble metals such as Pt, Pd, and Au were used to catalyze this reaction. More enhancements in this reaction were reported by Hutchings et al [4], indeed they showed that supported gold catalysts were very active for the liquid phase selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol. They investigated a range of supports and preparation methods and discovered that Fe2O3 supported gold catalysts prepared by co-precipitation method displayed the highest conversion. A screening of supports for gold catalysts was also performed by Choudhary et al [7]; the authors claimed that ZrO2, MnO2, Sm2O3, and Al2O3 were found to have the highest turnover frequencies. The synergistic influence of combining the Au with Pd was established, for selective oxidation benzyl alcohol [4]. The authors found the bimetallic catalysts to be more active than Au only catalysts but less active than Pd only catalysts. However bimetallic catalysts displayed, over the duration of the reaction, both higher conversions and selectivity towards benzaldehyde, 74%, and 91% respectively. In another report, Dimitratos et al [8] prepared Au catalyst with very small particle size and it showed higher activity than the catalysts prepared via impregnation. They also investigated the role of different calcination atmospheres and found out that air calcined samples are superior to the catalysts calcined under hydrogen or nitrogen. It is widely reported that CeZr mixed oxides possessed exceptional redox characteristics and huge lattice oxygen mobility [9]. These possessions powerfully be contingent on Ce/Zr molar ratio. Chloroauric acid (HAuCl4) has been widely used as a source to synthesize Au containing catalysts. However, chloride anion contained in the precursor often causes problems, such as coagulation of Au particles, poisoning of catalytic activity and corrosion of matrix materials [10]. To deposit fine Au nanoparticles on supports, co-precipitation or deposition-precipitation methods were employed [11], although incomplete washing by water will cause residual Cl− ions. Total organic synthesis routes have been widely utilized to synthesize novel materials; these methods have advantages that includes relatively simple procedures that allows for flexibility in introduction of foreign elements, composition control, scalability, and high purity [12]. In this work, we used novel organic deposition-precipitation method by utilizing gold acetate [Au(CH3COO)3] as a Cl-free gold precursor and tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide as hydrolyzing agent. The aim of this work is to synthesize nanosized Au supported CeZr and Sm modified Au-CeZr catalysts and use the synthesized materials for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol. This strategy was allowed us to obtain fine nanoparticles of Au, and the mild preparation conditions also lend themselves well to Sm modiﬁcation. In addition, structural properties of the catalysts were determined using various analytical techniques to correlate the oxidation catalytic activity of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All the reagents were procured from commercial suppliers and used as received. Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (Alfa-Asser, UK), gold acetate and samarium acetate and tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide were purchased from Aldrich, UK. Ethyl alcohol, benzyl alcohol, 99%, benzaldehyde, 99%, benzoic acid, 99% Sigma-Aldrich, decane, HPLC grade, Fisher Scientific, toluene, AR grade, Sigma-Aldrich, UK. Double distilled water was used in the preparation. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts The Au deposited CeZr catalysts with different Au loadings (0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1.0 wt%) were prepared by novel organic deposition-precipitation route. Calculated amount of commercial Au(OCH3COO)3 powder was dropped into ethanol and sonicated for two hours to form a brown colored solution. Calculated amount of CeZr powder was mixed with ethanoic gold precursor solution under constant stirring and the pH of the contents was adjusted to 10–11 by adding tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide solution. The stirring was continued for one hour and the excess of the solvent was removed by heating contents at 50 °C. The obtained powders were oven dried at 110 °C for 5 h and finally calcined at 500 °C for 5 h under the flow of air. The catalysts were symbolized as xAu-CeZr, where x = Au loading (0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1.0 wt%). The samarium (0.5, 1.0, 2.0 and 4.0 wt%) modified 0.5Au-CeZr catalysts were prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation of calcined 0.5Au-CeZr powder with solution of samarium acetate (99.9%, Acros) in ethanol: water mixed solvent (70%:30%). A sample containing only 2 wt.% of Sm over the CeZr support was also prepared for the sake of comparison. After the impregnation process, the Sm containing catalysts were treated as gold deposited samples. The samples were symbolized as xSm-0.5Au-CeZr, where x = Sm loading (0.5, 1.0, 2.0 and 4.0 wt%). 2.3 Characterization of catalyst samples The X-ray diffraction patterns of samples were obtained using Philips PW1700 diffractometer. A Cu Kα radiation and graphite monochromator with automatic divergent slit were utilized to conduct the XRD analysis. The obtained XRD patterns were compared with standard JCPDS files. The crystallite size of CeZr and Au crystallites were calculated from major reflections of CeZr and Au phases using the Scherrer equation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the samples obtained using JEOL JSM840 A instrument (JEOL, Japan). TEM analysis of the samples was performed using Philips CM200FEG microscope equipped with a field emission gun operated at 200 kV. High-resolution images with a pixel size of 0.044 nm were taken with a CCD camera. DRIFT spectra of calcined samples and pyridine adsorbed samples were collected using Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 FTIR spectrometer. The DRUV-vis reflectance spectra of the samples were collected using Thermo-Scientific evolution spectrophotometer conjugated with an integrating sphere in the wavelength range of 200–800 nm. N2-physisorption measurements for synthesized samples were carried at −196 °C using ASAP 2010 Micromeritics Instrument. Specific surface area (SBET) of the samples were determined by applying the BET equation. The average pore diameter was calculated by applying the BJH method. The X-ray photoelectron spectra of the samples were obtained using Thermo Scientific Escalab 250 Xi XPS instrument using Al Kα X-rays. The C1s peak binding energy was used for the correction of peak shift due to charge compensation. The reducibility of the catalysts was determined by an H2-temperature-programmed reduction using CHEMBET-3000 instrument (Quantachrome, USA). Typically, a sample of 50 mg was first pretreated with helium gas at 120 °C for 2 h, and then the temperature of the sample brought to 30 °C and subsequently the gas flow was switched from helium to H2 gas and the temperature of the sample raised from 30 °C to 700 °C with heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The response from the thermal conductivity detector were recorded to obtain H2-TPR patterns of the samples. 2.4 Oxidation of benzyl alcohol The benzyl alcohol oxidation experiments were conducted in a three-necked round-bottomed flask equipped with a reflux condenser. The reactions were performed at different reaction temperatures (precisely controlled oil bath) under atmospheric pressure. For typical oxidation reaction, benzyl alcohol (50 mmol) and 0.05 ml decane (use as external standard) was added with 0.1 g of catalyst. The resulting mixture was stirred at selected reaction temperature with a stirring speed of 500 rpm under 1 atm of O2. Liquid samples were taken from the round-bottomed flask for every 30 min and analyzed by gas chromatography GC (HP-6890) equipped with FID and HP-5 capillary column. The benzyl alcohol conversion was calculated based on the benzyl alcohol remained in the product solution after particular reaction time. The selectivity to the benzaldehyde was calculated as the amount of benzaldehyde divided by a number of total products and multiplied by 100. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Powder X-ray diffraction Powder XRD patterns of bare CeZr support and gold supported CeZr samples are shown in Fig.1 . The XRD pattern of the pure CeZr support is in accordance with the pattern presented for CexZr1-xO2 solid solution [13]. Characteristic XRD peaks attributed to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) planes of fluorite-type cubic structured CexZr1-xO2 were observed in CeZr and gold supported CeZr samples [14]. The XRD peak positions and intensities of Au deposited CeZr samples are almost same as bare CeZr sample [Fig. 1 (A)], which is an indication that CeZr crystalline structure is intact without changing its size after Au deposition. Absence of Au diffraction peaks were observed for the 0.1Au-CeZr and 0.2Au-CeZr samples indicating that the size of gold particles might be under the X-ray detection range (<5 nm) [15]. In contrast, presence of small diffraction peak at 2θ = 38.2° [JCPDS file: 04-0784] in case of 0.5Au-CeZr and 1.0Au-CeZr samples reveals that these samples possessed relatively big Au particles. The XRD patterns for Sm modified 0.5-Au-CeZr samples along with 2.0Sm-CeZr are shown in Fig. 1(B). The impregnation of Sm have not caused any noticeable changes in XRD pattern of Au deposited CeZr or bare CeZr materials. From Fig. 1(B), it is clear that no diffraction peaks due to the phase of samarium oxide was observed even in case of sample loaded with 4.0 wt% of Sm, indicating that Sm could have highly dispersed on the surface of the CeZr support. Previously, Prasad et al [16] observed shift in position of diffraction peaks and a slight enhancement in the lattice parameter in case of rare earth metal (La3+, Pr3+ and Sm3+) doped CeO2 samples mainly due to low ionic radii of the metal ions than the Ce4+. The lattice parameters for the Sm modified 0.5Au-CeZr samples using the most intense diffraction peak corresponding to (111) plane were calculated to understand the influence of addition of Sm gold deposited CeZr samples (Table 1 ). The lattice parameter for the bare CeZr, 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples was found to be 0.514, 0.515 and 0.513 nm respectively, indicating that deposition of Au and Sm have not incorporated in the crystal lattice of CeZr. The average crystallite size of catalysts was determined by using Scherrer equation (Table 1). The crystallite size of bare CeZr and Au-CeZr and Sm modified Au-CeZr samples was found to be in the range of 50–54 nm. The average size of CeZr crystallites was not significantly altered by the addition of Au and/or Sm. The average size of Au crystallites is in the range of 10–15 nm. Crystallite size of Au was not determined for 0.1Au-CeZr and 0.2Au-CeZr catalysts due to absence of the diffraction peaks due to Au crystallites. 3.2 Morphology studies The SEM image of bare CeZr clearly showed the particles with spherical and rod shaped morphologies (Fig. 2 ). From SEM images, it can be seen that the morphology of the support slightly changed after Au deposition and all catalysts appear to have more rod shaped particles in different sizes. The rod shaped particles are formed via agglomeration of individual support particles probably due to calcination of the samples at 500 °C. It was previously reported that Au supported CeO2-ZrO2 samples exhibits bright spots due to presence of Au nanoparticles with different diameters [17]. The bright spots are not observed in the SEM images of Au deposited samples, although the XRD patterns of 0.5Au-CeZr and 1.0Au-CeZr samples showed diffraction peaks due to Au particles. The gold particles generally appears as a bright spots in SEM images, but the spots were not observed due to high Au dispersion in these samples. The variation in morphology could be clearly seen in CeZr and Au-CeZr samples after Sm modification (Fig. 3 ). It is clear that Sm modification of Au-CeZr enhanced the agglomeration of the particles. The 0.5Au-CeZr samples that contained low Sm loading (0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 wt.%) are contained aggregates with some void spaces. In contrast, the aggregated particles were packed very closely to each other in case of 2.0Sm-CeZr and 4.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples (Fig. 3(d) and (e)). TEM analysis was carried out to investigate the morphology and structure of the samples. The TEM analysis clearly showed that the samples possessed two differently shaped CeZr nanoparticles maintain their original crystal shapes after Au deposition. The rod shaped CeZr display a width of 20 nm with a length of 100 nm, and the CeZr nanoparticles have a diameter in between 10 nm and 20 nm. The TEM images of the samples clearly revealed the attachment of nanosized Au particles with CeZr clusters. Fig. 4 (b) shows TEM image of 0.5Au-CeZr sample; as Au particles are in attachment with planes of CeZr and Akita et al [18] reported a similar observation. It can also observe a low Au particle growth in samples synthesized in this study compared with the samples synthesized by inorganic deposition-precipitation procedure [19]. In the TEM images of Sm promoted 0.5Au-CeZr samples, the distinguishing between Au and Sm metals was not possible majorly due to diffraction contrast. This phenomenon can be clearly observed in Fig. 4(d), where Au and Sm particles cannot be distinguished easily. The HRTEM analysis was performed for representative samples to differentiate Au nanoparticles from CeZr. The HRTEM images of the 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalysts are shown in Fig. 4(e) and (f) respectively. The HRTEM image of 0.5Au-CeZr sample reveal evidence of Au nanoparticles, the formation of Au nanoparticles was identified and differentiated by the lattice spacing measurements. The presence of respective planes with lattice spacing of 0.20 nm in Au-CeZr sample due to the (200) plane of Au and this is well acquainted with the results obtained in XRD data [20]. It could be seen that Au nanoparticles are well dispersed over the CeZr support. The 0.5Au-CeZr and 1.0Au-CeZr samples showed gold particles of average size of 20 nm and 25 nm respectively; however, in both samples Au particles are dispersed over the CeZr support. Dark spots on the surface of Au particles can be clearly observed in case of Sm promoted 0.5Au-CeZr catalysts. Notably, the HRTEM data did not reveal an evidence of formation of Sm clusters. This is possibly due to high dispersion of Sm on the surface of 0.5Au-CeZr catalyst. The average particle size of the Au nanoparticles supported over Sm modified 0.5Au-CeZr catalyst is estimated to be in the range of 12–14 nm and the size of CeZr samples is approximately 40 nm with fluorite cubic structure. The grain sizes of CeZr and Au presented in the samples determined from TEM analysis are slightly bigger than the crystallite sizes calculated by Scherrer equation from the XRD analysis; this is probably due to agglomeration of crystallites. High resolution TEM images of samples shows a clear evidence for the presence of Au nanoparticles and the lattice fringes of CuZr support and the Au particles are in close contact with CeZr surface. 3.3 Textural properties Nitrogen gas physisorption experiments were conducted to study the textural properties of the investigated samples (Fig. 5 (A)). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of CeZr support and Au supported CeZr materials appears same with type-III isotherms and H2 type hysteresis loop [21]. This observation is an indication that samples possessed macropores with inkpot-shaped pores having contracted necks and big cavities [22]. The flattening of the hysteresis loop was observed with Au deposition which indicates the change of volume of pores. From pore size distribution analysis (supplementary information, Fig S1) it is observed that the catalysts are given almost uniform pore size distribution. It is interesting to note that Sm impregnated CeZr and 0.5Au-CeZr samples showed type IV isotherms with H3 type hysteresis loop [Fig. 5 (B)] indicating that these samples possessed slit-shaped mesopores due to aggregates of particles [23]. A gradual increase in quantity of N2 adsorbed with increase of relative pressure can be seen in isotherms of the samples and it is an indication that the adsorption on these samples proceeded via multilayer formation. The pore radius peak (supplementary information, Fig. S1) is mainly centered between 90 Å and 150 Å indicating that Sm impregnated 0.5Au-CeZr samples also possessed meso pores. Table 2 represents the data obtained from N2 physisorption measurements. The surface area of the Au supported CeZr catalysts decreased from 58 m2 g−1 to 40 m2 g−1 due to deposition of Au, which is in accordance with observation of previous studies. The average the pore diameter also varied in between 190–205 Å. These values are indicating that the materials are mesoporous in nature and all of them similar pore structure. The pore volume of the samples also increased when the Sm loading was raised to 2.0 wt%. The pore volume of the 0.5Au-CeZr sample is higher (0.116 cm3 g-1) that of the 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr sample (0.096 cm3 g-1), further increase of the Sm loading caused decrease of pore volume. The variations in the textural properties of Sm impregnated 0.5Au-CeZr samples is majorly due to morphology changes after incorporation of Sm. 3.4 Acidity measurements Pyridine adsorption is a convenient technique to identify and quantify the Lewis and Brönsted acid sites presented in the samples [23,24]. It was reported that pyridine coordination with Lewis acid sites (pyL) leads to IR bands around 1600 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1, whereas, pyridinium ions conjugated with Brönsted acid sites (pyB) show bands at 1640 and 1540 cm-1 [24]. Fig. S2 shows FTIR spectra of the Au-CeZr and Sm-Au-CeZr samples after pyridine adsorption. The quantification of the Lewis (L) and Brönsted (B) acid sites was performed using the intensities of the bands observed at 1446 and 1546 cm−1 [25]. The Beer-Lambert equation was applied to calculate the quantitative data [26] and the results were presented in Table 3 . The bare CeZr support majorly possessed Lewis acid sites along with a minor quantity of Brönsted acid sites. The coordinated unsaturated Ce4+ and Zr4+ ions are responsible for the observed Lewis acidity of the CeZr support. After deposition of Au on CeZr support, the quantity of Lewis acid sites were increased. The increase of Lewis acidity could be attributed to the presence of oxidized Au species. The Sm impregnated 0.5Au-CeZr samples showed a different behavior that an increase of intensity of the absorption bands at 1446 cm−1 and 1604 cm−1, which are related to pyridine coordinated over Lewis acid sites. It is interesting to note that there is no change observed in the intensity of the bands due to Brönsted acid sites. Therefore, it is reasonably to argue that there is no influence of the addition of Sm on enhancing the concentration of surface hydroxyl groups. The 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples possessed the greater number of Lewis acid sites among all the investigated samples. 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements The XPS measurements for representative samples were performed to investigate the oxidation states of the elements presented in the synthesized catalysts and also the surface elemental composition of the samples. The deconvoluted Ce3d, Zr3d, O1s, Au4f and Sm4d XP spectra for CeZr, 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples are shown in Fig. 6 . It is known that Ce based materials exhibits multifaceted features because of hybridization of the Ce valence 4f orbital with ligand orbitals [27]. The Ce3d5/2 XP spectra of the catalysts are fitted with four different components at 880.4 eV, 882.5 eV, 885.5 eV and 888.5 eV; the peaks at 882.5 eV and 888.5 eV can be attributed to Ce4+, and the peaks at 880.4 eV and 885.5 eV are corresponding to the Ce3+ species respectively [28]. The appearance of the XPS peaks due to Ce3+ species indicates that the samples possessed some partially reduced Ce species with oxygen vacancies. Accordingly, it is possible to say that Ce existed together as Ce3+ and Ce4+ ions in all the samples. It is very clear from the peak intensities that Ce4+ species are prevailing than Ce3+ species. It was reported that the amount of partially reduced Ce species with oxygen vacancies is related to the particle size; the smaller particles possess a high concentration of oxygen vacancies [29]. The synthesized samples in the present study composed of nanosized CeZr particles (approximately 50 nm), thus a high concentration of oxygen vacancies is expected to be existed in the investigated samples. The Zr3d XP spectra of representative samples exhibited two peaks at 182.1 eV and 184.4 eV. The lower binding energy (BE) peak could be assigned to Zr 3d5/2 , whereas the peak at higher BE is due to Zr3d3/2 [30].The corresponding BE values for the two spin-orbit components in Zr3d spectra indicate the presence of Zr4+ions in the samples. It is known that the Zr4+ species in pure ZrO2 appears around 182.6 eV [31], the Zr species presented in the CeZr and Au-CeZr samples showed slightly lower BE values compared to pure ZrO2. The lower BE values is mainly due to the presence of oxygen vacancies in the CeZr crystal lattice [32]. The O1s spectra of the samples essentially composed of three peaks at 530 eV, 532 eV and 528.3 eV, which are denoted as Oa, Ob, and Oc respectively (Fig. 6). Navio et al [33] observed two different oxygen species in supported ZrO2 samples; oxygen species in ZrO2 and Zr-OH appeared around 530 eV and 532 eV respectively. Thus, the observed Oa and Ob peaks could be assigned to oxygen presented in CeZr lattice and hydroxyl groups on the surface of the CeZr support [34]. The Oc peak is due to the Ce2O3 species and the contribution of this peak is different for different samples. In Au and Sm deposited CeZr samples, a shift in the BE values for O1s peaks towards higher values was observed mainly due to the interaction between Au/Sm metals and oxygen species of CeZr support. The XP spectra of Au4f for 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples show a major doublet corresponding to Au4f7/2 and Au4f5/2 states at 83.8 eV and 87.5 eV respectively [35]. It was also shown that Au4f7/2 peak was appeared at 84.0 eV, 84.6 eV and 86.6 eV for Au0, Au+ and Au3+ species respectively [36]. The corresponding BE values of both Au4f states clearly confirm the presence of Au° and Au3+species in the 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples. Thus, it can be concluded that Au species residing in this sample are mainly metallic in nature. Presence of XP peak due to an oxidic gold at 86.6 eV and increase in area under XP peak due to Ce4+ clearly indicates existence of the Au/Sm-CeZr interaction in Au deposited CeZr catalysts. The deconvoluted Ce3d, Zr3d, O1s and Au4f XP spectra for calcined 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr sample is very similar as 0.5Au-CeZr sample. However, there are few differences observed in XP spectra of this sample after Sm modification. The lattice oxygen of CeZr support becomes liable (appearance of O1s peak at 529.0 eV; lower BE than normal). Two peaks with BE of 136.4 eV (Sm4d3/2 ) and 132.1 eV (Sm4d5/2 ) are found in the high-resolution spectrum of the Sm modified 0.5-Au-CeZr sample. It was reported that samarium oxide (Sm2O3) shows Sm4d XPS peak at 135.6 eV [37]. The appearance of two XPS peaks clearly indicating that there are two types Sm species presented on the surface of this sample. The peak at 136.4 eV can be attributed to Sm3+ species and the other peak at 132.1 eV could be due to presence of Smδ+ species, which are generated because of interaction of Sm with Au and/or CeZr. The quantitative data obtained from XPS analysis is presented in Table S1. The investigated samples possessed Ce3+ species in the range of 25–29%. The 0.5Au-CeZr sample exhibited the composition of 88% Au° and 12% of oxidized Au species, on other hand 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr sample showed 73% Au° and 27% of oxidized Au species. The 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples possessed surface Au° composition of 0.34% and 0.4% respectively. The Ce 3d XP spectra were used to quantify the Ce3+ and Ce4+ species presented in the samples, since the Ce3+ composition provides vital information pertained to CeZr modification by Au and Sm metals. The results indicating that Au-CeZr and Sm-Au-CeZr samples possessed relatively lower concentration of Ce3+ species compared to bare CeZr support. It is also observed that the intensity ratio between Ce3+/Ce4+ peaks decreases considerably and the BE of Ce3+ shifts to higher values after Au and Sm modification. This observation reveals the decrease of negative charge density on CeZr lattice after Au and Sm modification. This may be due to the formation of Au-CeZr and/or Sm-CeZr by utilization of surface hydroxyl groups of CeZr support. 3.6 H2-TPR measurements H2-TPR experiments have been carried out for all the synthesized samples in order to investigate the redox properties of the catalysts (Fig.7 ). The bare CeZr support exhibited two reduction peaks centered at 425 °C and 640 °C. The peak at 425 °C can be attributed to the reduction of surface oxygen species and the peak at 640 °C is related to the reduction of bulk oxygen of CeO2 [38]. No reduction peak due to reduction of Zr (IV) was observed since ZrO2 is generally reduced at very high temperature (beyond 800 °C). For Au deposited CeZr catalysts, the reduction peak shifted to lower temperature region. The peak shifting indicates the promotion of Ce4+ reduction and it related to enhancement of mobility and diffusion of bulk oxygen due to the addition of gold [39]. Appearance of reduction peaks at lower temperatures indicates that the catalyst surface is easily reducible in nature and this reduced catalyst surface gives better activity towards oxidation reaction. With increasing Au content both the reduction peaks are slightly shifted to lower temperature. This peak shifting suggested that Au deposition has a prominent effect on redox performance. It also be noted that the quantity of H2 consumed increased with increasing Au concentration, and hence the extent of reduction increased with increasing Au content. The hydrogen consumption values were determined from H2-TPR patterns of the samples and the values are presented in Table S2. The extent of the reduction is relatively high in case of 0.5Au-CeZr sample, as it showed hydrogen consumption of 1.02 mmol g−1, on other hand 0.2Au-CeZr and 1.0Au-CeZr samples showed very close values 0.85 and 0.88 mmol g−1, respectively. This observation revealing the influence of Au loading on the reducibility of CeZr support. It is known that the reduction of finely dispersed Au nanoparticles on CeZr surface occurs at low temperature and the reduction of the large gold agglomerates occurs at high temperature [40]. The H2-TPR profiles of Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples are very similar as 0.5Au-CeZr sample, however the reduction temperatures were shifted to high temperatures after Sm impregnation. A similar behavior was observed in case of 2.0Sm-CeZr sample. The impregnation of Sm with 0.5Au-CeZr did not affected the cubic fluorite structure, this is possibly due to the ionic radius of Sm3+ (0.096 nm) is very close to Ce4+(0.103 nm) [41]. The shift in the reduction temperatures observed in the Sm-0.5Au-CeZr samples is mainly due to strong interaction between Sm and Au-CeZr. It is known that metal-metal or metal-metal oxide interactive species required high temperature to reduce compared with isolated metal species [36]. The H2 consumption values for all the Sm loaded 0.5Au-CeZr catalysts is shown in Table S2. In case of 0.5Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalyst hydrogen consumption is more comparable to 0.5Au-CeZr catalyst, with increase of Sm loading on 0.5Au-CeZr, the H2 consumption was further increased. These observations indicating that the impregnated Sm is highly distributed over the 0.5Au-CeZr sample. 3.7 Oxidation of benzyl alcohol The synthesized nanosized gold supported CeZr materials were used as catalysts for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. The reaction was performed using CeZr support under different reaction conditions along with Au deposited CeZr and Sm modified Au-CeZr catalysts. The influence of reaction temperature on the performance of catalysts in oxidation of benzyl alcohol was studied in the range of 70–100 °C, by maintaining other parameters constant. The data obtained from the catalytic tests are presented in Fig. 8 and Table 4 . The bare CeZr support did not offered any conversion of benzyl alcohol at 70 °C, however conversion levels were increased from 70 to 100 °C, (with maximum 9% at 100 °C) with benzaldehyde selectivity around 94%. The selected maximum reaction temperature is 100 °C majorly due to the fact that temperatures higher than 100 °C could obstruct the selective oxidation process [42]. The data presented in the Table 4 indicating a minor drop in selectivity of benzaldehyde was noticed after increasing the reaction temperature from 70 to 100 °C. After 0.1 wt% Au deposition on CeZr support, the benzyl alcohol conversion levels were increased significantly to 15% at 70 °C, with increase of temperature to 100 °C, the conversion reached to 30%. Increase of Au loading from 0.1 to 0.5 wt% resulted drastic increase of conversion levels, the highest conversion (80%) was observed for 0.5Au-CeZr catalyst at 100 °C. The selectivity to benzaldehyde also increased slightly from 96% to 99% with increase of Au loading from 0.1 wt% to 0.5 wt%. Further increase of Au loading to 1.0 wt% resulted decrease of benzyl alcohol conversion to 55% and selectivity to benzaldehyde to 98%. From these observations, it is clear that the 0.5 wt % is the optimum Au loading over CeZr support to obtain high catalytic performance in benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction. Different loadings of Sm were impregnated over 0.5Au-CeZr catalyst, because it the best catalyst among the Au-CeZr catalysts. With 0.5 wt% Sm loading, the conversion levels are not increased significantly, however increase of loading to 1.0 wt% led to increase of conversion levels from 75% to 85% at 100 °C for 1.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr. Increase of Sm loading to 2.0 wt% resulted the increase of conversion levels to 95% at 100 °C, however further increase of Sm loading (4.0 wt%) led to decrease of conversion of benzyl alcohol. These results are indicating that 2.0 wt% of Sm is the optimum loading to promote the Au-CeZr catalysts. To compare, 2.0Sm-CeZr catalyst (without gold) was also tested for benzyl alcohol oxidation, but it offered only 42.3% conversion at 100 °C. It appears that presence of Au is necessary to get high activity in aerobic oxidation. Interestingly, all Sm impregnated catalysts showed very high selectivity to benzaldehyde. Influence of reaction time over the catalytic performance of synthesized catalysts was also investigated. The variation of benzyl alcohol conversion levels and selectivity to benzaldehyde of all the catalysts is presented in Fig. 9 . With increase in reaction time, the benzyl alcohol conversion levels for all the catalyst were increased, however the selectivity to benzaldehyde decreased continuously. The decrease of selectivity of benzaldehyde is majorly due to its sequential oxidation, which is preferred with increase of reaction time. In case of Au deposited CeZr catalysts, the conversion levels reached plateau after 9 h of the reaction. It is interesting to note that the Sm impregnated 0.5Au-CeZr catalysts showed a linear increase of conversion levels with reaction time and these catalysts offered highest conversion within 6 h. These observations are again indicating the influence of rare earth metals in promoting the ability of Au-CeZr catalysts in benzyl alcohol oxidation. The effect of catalyst amount on the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol was studied by taking different weight of catalysts (CeZr, 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr) and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 10 . In case of bare CeZr support, the oxidation rate increased from 1.0 to 4.5%, as the weight of catalyst increased from 0.03 g to 0.1 g. Further increase of catalyst amount, decrease of benzaldehyde selectivity was observed although benzyl alcohol conversion levels remained constant for all the catalysts. The decrease in benzaldehyde selectivity is essentially due to the oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. The optimum catalyst amount of catalyst was observed as 0.1 g. The conversion levels increased linearly as the amount of 0.5Au-CeZr and 0.5Au-2.0Sm-CeZr catalysts increased from 0.03 g to 0.07 g, further increase of catalyst amount to 0.1 g led to increase of conversion, however it is not linear. It was observed that introduction of Zr4+ ions into the CeO2 fluorite lattice improves the oxygen storage capacity and the formation of oxygen vacancies [24]. Recently Olmos et al [43] utilized Au-Pd supported CeZr catalysts for benzyl alcohol oxidation, they reported that benzyl alcohol is first oxidized to benzaldehyde via an alkoxy intermediate. The 0.5Au-CeZr sample showed superior catalytic performance than other synthesized samples, which might be due to the fact that the sample contained lower sized gold nanoparticles. The organic deposition-precipitation route adapted in the present study yielded gold nanoparticles that are larger (20–30 nm) than the optimal size reported in the literature (≈5 nm) for oxidation reactions [44]. Although, the size of gold particles is higher than desired, the crystallites are able to interact with CeZr support (as evidenced by TEM and H2-TPR results) and able to enhance the rate of benzyl alcohol reaction. Gutiérez-Ortiz et al [45] previously reported that acidity and accessible lattice oxygen species of CeZr plays an important role in obtaining better catalytic activity oxidation reaction. It was widely acknowledged that deprotonation of alcohol molecule is the primary step in reaction mechanism of benzyl alcohol oxidation and the rate limiting step is the β-hydride elimination to form aldehyde or carboxylic acid on the surface of gold nanoparticles. The observed superior catalytic activity of Au deposited CeZr samples could be related to presence of moderate number of surface acid sites and the ability of Au nanoparticles to weaken the surface Ce-O bonds neighboring to gold nanoparticles, thus, enhancing the reactivity of the CeO2 surface oxygen, which involves in oxidation reaction mechanism [46,47]. Impregnation of Sm to Au supported CeZr catalysts resulted further increase of the benzyl alcohol oxidation activity due to the enhancement in reducibility of the catalysts as these catalysts showed high degree of reduction (more amount of hydrogen consumption). The increase in catalytic activity was observed despite the fact that the Lewis acid sites for Sm-Au-CeZr catalysts were increased after impregnation of Sm (Fig. S2 and Table 3). The comparison of acidity and reducibility of the 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalysts indicating that both catalysts differ in their total number of acid sites and amount of hydrogen consumption. The total number acid sites and H2 consumption values of 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr is higher than that of 0.5Au-CeZr, indicates that the prior catalyst possessed high number of acid sites to deprotonate the benzyl alcohol and mobility of oxygen species to form oxygenated product. The performance of most active synthesized catalysts in this study is compared with the gold supported metal oxide catalysts reported in the literature (Table 5 ). Hutchings et al [4] deposited Au nanoparticles on different metal oxide supports and they observed that Au-Fe2O3 offered the highest benzyl alcohol conversion, however Au-TiO2 showed the high benzaldehyde selectivity. Choudhary et al [7] observed Au supported on ZrO2 and Sm2O3 showed considerably high benzyl alcohol oxidation rates. However, the catalysts synthesized in this study offered much higher benzyl alcohol conversion levels than the catalysts reported in the previous studies. Reusability of the catalyst is an important aspect in development of heterogeneous catalyst for a chemical process. Reusability tests for synthesized catalysts were performed by filtering the catalyst from the reaction mixture after end of the reaction. The filtered catalyst was washed thoroughly with acetone and then dried at 100 °C for 1 h to activate the catalyst. The dried catalyst was used for consequent run under same reaction conditions. The reusability of the 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalysts was tested for oxidation of benzyl alcohol under the identical reaction conditions. The performance of catalysts at different cycles in oxidation of benzyl alcohol was presented in Fig. 11 . The results indicated that 0.5Au-CeZr and 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalysts can be recycled for six times with stable activity. A small decrease in benzyl alcohol conversion level (2%) after fourth cycle and a total 3% drop in conversion was observed after sixth cycle. It is interesting to note that benzaldehyde selectivity was maintained almost constant during the reusability of the catalysts. These observations indicating that the synthesized catalysts are resistant to deactivation in oxidation reaction of benzyl alcohol. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, Au supported CeZr and Sm modified Au-CeZr nanocrystalline catalysts were successfully synthesized by novel deposition-precipitation method using organic precursors and precipitation agent. The XRD results reveals a small drop in crystallite size of CeZr after Au deposition and Sm impregnation, which could primarily attributed to restructuring of the CeZr surface. The TEM investigation of catalysts showed a homogeneous distribution of gold nanoparticles with 20–30 nm size on CeZr surface. A detailed XPS study reveals the presence of strong interaction between Au and CeZr particles. H2-TPR studies indicated that Sm modified Au-CeZr catalysts enhances the reducibility of the catalyst. The increased catalytic performance of Sm modified Au-CeZr catalysts in comparison with bare CeZr support and Au-CeZr samples can be attributed to their enhanced acidic, redox properties and also ability to resist the deactivation. coredata.dc:description: In this study, Au-Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (Au-CeZr) and Sm modified AuCeZr catalysts were synthesized by organic deposition-precipitation method using gold acetate and samarium acetate as Au and Sm precursors and tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide as precipitating agent. The synthesized nanocrystalline Au-CeZr and Sm modified Au-CeZr materials found be effective catalysts for benzyl alcohol oxidation at low reaction temperatures. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM, DRIFT spectra after pyridine adsorption, N2-physisorption, XPS and H2-TPR techniques. The Au nanoparticles are highly dispersed on CeZr support and XRD reflections due to presence of Au metal were not observed for the samples which contained less than 1.0 wt% Au. The XPS and H2-TPR results revealed that at lower Au loadings, strong Au-CeZr interaction resulted an easy exclusion of surface oxygen ions in Au-CeZr and Sm-Au-CeZr catalysts. Pyridine adsorption results indicated an increase of Lewis acid sites of the CeZr support after Au deposition and Sm modification. The 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalyst is most active and selective catalysts for benzyl alcohol oxidation among the synthesized catalysts due to optimum loading of Au and Sm. An optimal surface acidity and redox properties is accountable for the improved catalytic activity of 2.0Sm-0.5Au-CeZr catalyst in the benzyl alcohol oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Nanosized samarium modified Au-Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 catalysts for oxidation of benzyl alcohol
